details.title: A Classification Tree Based Approach for the Development of Minimal Cut and Path Vectors of a Capacitated Network
details.standardTitle: A Classification Tree Based Approach for the Development of Minimal Cut and Path Vectors of a Capacitated Network

p: Jose Emamnuel Ramirez-Marquez is an Assistant Professor at Stevens Institute of Technology in the School of Systems and Enterprises. His research interests include system reliability and quality assurance, uncertainty modeling, advanced heuristics for system reliability analysis, applied probability and statistical models, and applied operations research. He has authored more than 20 articles in leading technical journals, and has conducted funded research for both government, and commercial organizations on these topics. He obtained his Ph.D. at Rutgers University in Industrial and Systems Engineering, and received his B.S. degree in Actuarial Science from the UNAM in Mexico City in 1998. He also holds M.S. degrees in Industrial Engineering, and Statistics from Rutgers University. He is a member of IIE, IFORS, and INFORMS.

Bethel A. Gebre received her BE (2004) in Electrical Engineering with Minors in Computer Engineering, and Mathematical Sciences from Stevens Institute of Technology. She is a scholar of the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), and a member of the national engineering honor society Tau-Beta-Pi. She graduated with a Masters Degree in Systems Engineering and Engineering Management from Stevens Institute of Technology where she was a graduate research assistant working in topics related to network reliability, and criticality assessment.

details.abstract: This paper presents a holistic method that links together Monte-Carlo simulation, exact algorithms, and a data mining technique, to develop approximate bounds on the reliability of capacitated two-terminal networks. The method uses simulation to generate network configurations that are then evaluated with exact algorithms to investigate if they correspond to a network success or failure. Subsequently, the method implements commercially available software to generate a classification tree that can then be analyzed, and transformed into capacitated minimal cut or path vectors. These vectors correspond to the capacitated version of binary minimal cuts & paths of a network. This is the first time that these vectors are obtained from a decision tree, and in this respect, research efforts have been focused on two main directions: 1) deriving an efficient yet intuitive approach to simulate network configurations to obtain the most accurate information; and given that the classification tree method could for some applications provide imperfect or incomplete information without the explicit knowledge of the reliability engineer, 2) understand the relationship between the obtained vectors, and the real capacitated minimal cut & path vectors of the network, and its reliability. The proposed method has been tested on a set of case networks to assess its validity & accuracy. The results obtained show that the technique described is effective, simple, and widely applicable.

links.abstract: A new technique for determining the terminal reliability of probabilistic networks is derived and discussed. The technique uses set-theoretic concepts to partition the space of all graph realizations in a way which permits extremely fast evaluation of the source-to-terminal probability. If not allowed to run to completion, the algorithm yields rapidly converging upper and lower bounds on that probability. Comparison with algorithms in the recent literature shows a decrease of one or two orders o...

context.text: This problem has been extensively studied during the past few decades, and various algorithms have been proposed for its solution [1]–[3].

links.abstract: For calculating terminal-pair reliability, most published algorithms are based on the sum of disjoint products. However, these tree-based partitions lack the capability to avoid redundant computation due to the isomorphic sub-problems. To overcome these problems, an efficient methodology to evaluate the terminal-pair reliability, based on edge expansion diagrams using OBDD (ordered binary decision diagram) is presented. First, the success path function of a given network is constructed based on ...

links.abstract: A new efficient method that compensates for unreliable nodes in network reliability computations is presented. This method can be embedded in the modified Dotson algorithm or any algorithm that generates a symbolic reliability expression for networks with perfect nodes. Its cost increases linearly with the number of links, and the effect of unreliable nodes can be directly computed. This method supplants the Aggarwal method and other methods of compensating for unreliable nodes in the calculatio...

links.abstract: This paper presents an efficient cutset approach to compute the reliability of a large communication network having heterogeneous link capacities. The reliability measure has been defined as capacity related reliability (CRR). The proposed method, subset cut technique (SCT), requires the cutset information of the network. For each minimal cut C/sub i/, and a given minimum bandwidth requirement W/sub min/, the method enumerates all nonredundant subset cut (SC), where each SC relates link capaciti...

context.text:
Minimal Cut Set as denoted by [4]
.

In reality, most of these networks operate to provide some kind of demand between a specified set of nodes [4], usually called source, and sink, where the source node can be thought of as the origin, and the sink node as the destination.
That is, reliability for capacitated networks is a mixture of source-sink connectivity, and component capacity [4]–[6].
However, as discussed by some researchers [4], [10], even for mid-sized networks, current techniques usually fail to generate correct results, or are too costly in terms of computational time.

Elsayed [15] defines a binary path set as a set of components that guarantees system success. for capacitated networks, reliability can be considered as a hybrid of connectivity, and capacity [4]–[6]; and thus, the binary definition of path, and cut sets must be modified.

The capacitated version of a binary minimal path set (i.e. the CMPV) should consider not only components that guarantee \$s-t\$ connectivity success, but also the capacity levels at which these components guarantee \$s-t\$ capacity success [4]–[6].

As mentioned by Soh & Rai [4], the time complexity of this method increases exponentially with the number of binary minimal paths of the network. in this respect, Soh & Rai [4] developed a method based on a set transformation technique that allows the computation of capacitated minimal cut sets based on the a-priori knowledge of the equivalent binary sets.

Based on the discussions presented in references [4], and [10], it is evident that most of the algorithms currently available for the reliability analysis of capacitated network are both too complex, and obscure, or do not yield accurate results.
According to [4], if one uses the methods discussed in [10], and [20] the time complexity to generate composite paths is exponential in the number of simple paths of the network.

The approach presented in [4] provides CMCV for a network similar to Network 1 in Fig. 9, with the only difference being that the direction of arc 5 is reversed. for this network, the approach previously described was implemented with the same data structure described in Table VIII.
The second column shows the minimal cut sets published in [4].

Moreover, based on the minimal path and cut sets obtained, and assuming arc reliability equals 0.9, the proposed bound for the reliability of the network yields (0.9468, 0.9499), while the reliability reported by [4] equals 0.949844.

references.title:
An efficient cutset approach for evaluating communication-network
reliability with heterogeneous link-capacities

links.abstract: This paper presents a method for evaluating reliability of a flow network using the concept of lexicographic ordering. Associated with each branch of the network are the flow capacity and the probability that the branch functions properly. The network is successful if a specified units of flow can be transmitted through the network. A labeling scheme is used to route the flow through the network and a computer program for implementing the algorithm is given in the Supplement.

context.text: To correctly analyze these networks, it is necessary that the capacity of the links involved in source to sink connectivity can also handle the required demand [5].
That is, reliability for capacitated networks is a mixture of source-sink connectivity, and component capacity [4]–[5][6].

Elsayed [15] defines a binary path set as a set of components that guarantees system success. for capacitated networks, reliability can be considered as a hybrid of connectivity, and capacity [4]–[5][6]; and thus, the binary definition of path, and cut sets must be modified.

The capacitated version of a binary minimal path set (i.e. the CMPV) should consider not only components that guarantee \$s-t\$ connectivity success, but also the capacity levels at which these components guarantee \$s-t\$ capacity success [4]–[5][6].
Lee [5] modified the 2TR definition to account for this consideration, and proposed an algorithm based on the concept of lexicographic ordering, and cardinality reduction of vectors.

Aggarwal et al. [16] extended the work done by Lee [5] by proposing a method that identifies different combinations of binary minimal path sets that can guarantee that demand between source and sink nodes is fulfilled.

links.abstract: Two important characteristics for the performance of a telecommunication network are its reliability and capacity. Previous analytic methods have been used either to determine the reliability or capacity disregarding the other parameter. This leads to erroneous conclusions about the performance of the network. This paper suggests a method to integrate these two important measures by defining a weighted reliability index. The states which lead to at least one available path between the terminal n...

context.text: That is, reliability for capacitated networks is a mixture of source-sink connectivity, and component capacity [4]–[6].

Elsayed [15] defines a binary path set as a set of components that guarantees system success. for capacitated networks, reliability can be considered as a hybrid of connectivity, and capacity [4]–[6]; and thus, the binary definition of path, and cut sets must be modified.

The capacitated version of a binary minimal path set (i.e. the CMPV) should consider not only components that guarantee \$s-t\$ connectivity success, but also the capacity levels at which these components guarantee \$s-t\$ capacity success [4]–[6].
Aggarwal [6] later improved the method by modifying the steps related to the calculation of the capacity in the new combinations identified.

links.abstract: Network reliability analysis is usually based on minimal path or cut enumeration from which the associated reliability expressions are deduced. The cut-set method is a popular approach in the reliability analysis of many systems from simple to complex configurations. The computational requirements necessary to determine the minimal cut-sets of a network depend mainly on the number of minimal paths between the source and the sink. A technique designated as the "Path Tracing Algorithm" is presente...

links.abstract: An efficient method is proposed to evaluate the network reliability with variable link capacities when the simple paths of the network are known. Most of the evaluation techniques proposed in the literature so far are based on enumerating the k-composite paths, each of which is a union of k simple paths. Although some of those methods lead to correct results, the redundancy is still quite large and may occur repeatedly each time the higher order composite paths are generated. This paper proposes...

context.text: However, as discussed by some researchers [4], [10], even for mid-sized networks, current techniques usually fail to generate correct results, or are too costly in terms of computational time.
Moreover, Rai & Soh [20], and Lee & Park [10] showed that this method usually fails to generate correct results.
Moreover, the algorithm has proven impractical for even moderate size networks because of the number of branches that have to be analyzed [10].

To generate these sets, the technique relies on the application of the max-flow min-cut theorem [21]. with respect to this approach, Lee & Park [10] mentioned that the number of repeated sets obtained is significantly large, and increases with the number of iterations.

Based on the discussions presented in references [4], and [10], it is evident that most of the algorithms currently available for the reliability analysis of capacitated network are both too complex, and obscure, or do not yield accurate results.
According to [4], if one uses the methods discussed in [10], and [20] the time complexity to generate composite paths is exponential in the number of simple paths of the network.

An efficient method for evaluating network-reliability with
variable link-capacities
references.text: S. Lee, D. Park, "An efficient method for evaluating network-reliability with variable link-capacities", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 50, no. 4, pp. 374-379, 2001.

context.text: The use of classification techniques for reliability analysis is not new, but has been restricted to a handful of researchers [11]–[13].

The analysis methods developed by Rocco & Muselli [11]–[13] classify network states based on an evaluating function (EF), and then generate rules that can be associated with the CMCV, and CMPV of the network.

This aspect is concerned with the stochastic nature of the network, and its components. in this respect, current methods [11]–[13] are neither clear, nor specific on an approach to generate these network states.

This model is constructed from a user specified sample of network configurations that are generated from the stochastic behavior of its components. in this respect, Rocco & Muselli [11] have provided two machine learning algorithms to generate an approximate reliability expression for the network.
Unfortunately, current methods based on rule generation techniques [11]–[13] are neither clear, nor specific on how to manipulate \${\bf p}_{i}\$ to develop the maximum number of rules.
However, without these sets, simulation techniques such as those discussed by Rocco & Muselli [11], [12] can be used to generate system data, and this method would still be applicable.

It is important to mention that the only previous method related to CT [11] for network reliability analysis can generate an approximate reliability expression (ARE) containing only disjoint terms from which \$2{\rm TR}_{d}\$ can be approximated.
Current techniques [11]–[13] discuss that the data generated should be unique in the sense that state vectors should not be repeated.
Network analyzed by Rocco & Muselli [11].

The first part of this section illustrates the accuracy & validity of the new method proposed through the analysis of C2TR for four different test networks. in the second part, bounds are generated, and compared with the results for the only network that has been analyzed with other classification techniques [11]–[13].

Rocco & Muselli [11] originally analyzed the network presented in Fig. 12. in their study, they considered that each arc had a nominal capacity of 100 units, and that the network is functioning if a demand of 200 units can be delivered from source to sink.

links.abstract: Frequency, duration and availability are key measures in the evaluation of complex networks. Although efficient techniques have been developed, the calculation of these indexes is, however very difficult in certain type of networks, such as complex capacity-limited networks or in k-terminal problems. In this paper the machine learning algorithm Hamming clustering (HC), belonging to the family of rule generation methods, is employed to obtain an approximated availability expression (AE) for a net...

context.text: The use of classification techniques for reliability analysis is not new, but has been restricted to a handful of researchers [11]–[12][13].

The analysis methods developed by Rocco & Muselli [11]–[12][13] classify network states based on an evaluating function (EF), and then generate rules that can be associated with the CMCV, and CMPV of the network.

This aspect is concerned with the stochastic nature of the network, and its components. in this respect, current methods [11]–[12][13] are neither clear, nor specific on an approach to generate these network states.
Further research by Rocco & Muselli [12] has lead to the application of the Hamming clustering technique to provide frequency, duration, and availability indices in complex networks.
Unfortunately, current methods based on rule generation techniques [11]–[12][13] are neither clear, nor specific on how to manipulate \${\bf p}_{i}\$ to develop the maximum number of rules.
However, without these sets, simulation techniques such as those discussed by Rocco & Muselli [11], [12] can be used to generate system data, and this method would still be applicable.
Current techniques [11]–[12][13] discuss that the data generated should be unique in the sense that state vectors should not be repeated.

The first part of this section illustrates the accuracy & validity of the new method proposed through the analysis of C2TR for four different test networks. in the second part, bounds are generated, and compared with the results for the only network that has been analyzed with other classification techniques [11]–[12][13].

references.text: C. Rocco, M. Muselli, "A Machine Learning Approach to Estimate Frequency Duration & Availability Indexes in Complex Networks", Proceedings of the Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, 2005.

context.text: The use of classification techniques for reliability analysis is not new, but has been restricted to a handful of researchers [11]–[13].

The analysis methods developed by Rocco & Muselli [11]–[13] classify network states based on an evaluating function (EF), and then generate rules that can be associated with the CMCV, and CMPV of the network.

This aspect is concerned with the stochastic nature of the network, and its components. in this respect, current methods [11]–[13] are neither clear, nor specific on an approach to generate these network states.

Similarly, this technique has also been applied to the problem of analyzing network reliability where the components of the network have multiple states ranging from perfect functioning to completely failed [13].
Unfortunately, current methods based on rule generation techniques [11]–[13] are neither clear, nor specific on how to manipulate \${\bf p}_{i}\$ to develop the maximum number of rules.
Current techniques [11]–[13] discuss that the data generated should be unique in the sense that state vectors should not be repeated.

The first part of this section illustrates the accuracy & validity of the new method proposed through the analysis of C2TR for four different test networks. in the second part, bounds are generated, and compared with the results for the only network that has been analyzed with other classification techniques [11]–[13].

links.abstract: Two recently proposed performance indexes for telecommunication networks are shown to be the s-t and overall versions of the same measure, namely, the mean normalized network capacity. The network capacity is a pseudo-switching-function of the branch successes, and hence it means value is readily obtainable from its sum-of-products expression. Three manual techniques of conventional reliability analysis are adapted for the computation of the proposed performance indexes: a map procedure, reducti...

links.abstract: A new method for reliability analysis of stochastic flow networks is proposed. Nodes as well as branches can have limited capacities and can fail. The method builds a branching tree. The tree-nodes are the disjoint terms of a symbolic reliability expression. The paper shows how to find the probability function and mean of the network performance. The method is both simple and effective. The minimal paths or cutsets are not needed explicitly. On a computer the memory effort is very low ¿ it incre...

The method is a two-step approach. The first step deals with composite path enumeration (CPE). A k-composite path is defined as the union of the set of edges in any k simple paths and relates link capacity and network connectivity. The CPE approach is an improvement over the algorithms proposed by the autho...

context.text: Moreover, Rai & Soh [20], and Lee & Park [10] showed that this method usually fails to generate correct results.

The method provided by Rai & Soh [20] enumerates all network states guaranteeing network success, and proposes a technique to generate the capacitated version of binary minimal path sets denoted as composite path sets.
According to [4], if one uses the methods discussed in [10], and [20] the time complexity to generate composite paths is exponential in the number of simple paths of the network.

references.title:
A computer Approach for the reliability evaluation of telecommunication
networks with heterogeneous link-capacities
references.text: S. Rai, S. Soh, "A computer Approach for the reliability evaluation of telecommunication networks with heterogeneous link-capacities", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 40, pp. 441-451, 1991.

context.text: The purpose of this paper is to link Monte-Carlo (MC) simulation, exact algorithms, and a data mining technique to develop a method that provides: 1) capacitated minimal cut, and path vectors (i.e. the capacitated version of binary minimal cut, and path sets); and based on these vectors, 2) lower, and upper bounds on the value of C2TR. from an overall perspective, the method uses MC simulation to generate network states (network configurations); then, the method developed by Gebre & Ramirez-Marquez [26], together with the max-flow min-cut theorem [21], is used to evaluate if the states previously generated correspond to a network success or failure.

To generate these sets, the technique relies on the application of the max-flow min-cut theorem [21]. with respect to this approach, Lee & Park [10] mentioned that the number of repeated sets obtained is significantly large, and increases with the number of iterations.

After balanced data has been generated, and both \$\Omega\$, and \$\Gamma\$ have been satisfied, each of the network state vectors, along with its associated network state (dictated by the EF), will be fed into CART. in this respect, the EF used to obtain the network state \$\varphi({\bf x})\$ associated with network state vector \${\bf x}\$ is dictated by the max-flow min-cut theorem [21].

Once this vector has been generated, Sector 1.2 uses the binary minimal cut sets of G, along with the max-flow min-cut theorem [21] to evaluate if \${\bf x}_{u}\$ corresponds to a network failure or success, \$\varphi_{u}<d\$ or \$\varphi_{u}\geq d\$ respectively.

context.text: Finally, Rocco & Moreno [22], and Rocco & Zio [23] have generated simulation approaches based on cellular automata algorithms to obtain an estimate of two-terminal, k-terminal, and all-terminal network reliability under the assumption of binary network components.

context.text: The purpose of this paper is to link Monte-Carlo (MC) simulation, exact algorithms, and a data mining technique to develop a method that provides: 1) capacitated minimal cut, and path vectors (i.e. the capacitated version of binary minimal cut, and path sets); and based on these vectors, 2) lower, and upper bounds on the value of C2TR. from an overall perspective, the method uses MC simulation to generate network states (network configurations); then, the method developed by Gebre & Ramirez-Marquez [26], together with the max-flow min-cut theorem [21], is used to evaluate if the states previously generated correspond to a network success or failure.
Obtain minimal cut sets from \$s\$ to \$t\$ for network; G; the approach by Gebre & Ramirez-Marquez [26] can be used.

The method presented by Gebre & Ramirez-Marquez [26] yields the following binary minimal cut sets: {8, 9}, {4, 5, 9}, {6, 7, 8}, {1, 5, 9}, {4, 5, 6}, {2, 3, 7, 8}, {1, 5, 6}, {2, 3, 4}, and {1, 2}. for this example, \$U=10,000\$, \$\delta=0.01\$, \$\Delta=0.1\$, \$\omega=0.8\$, and \$\gamma=0.05\$. for this network, \$p_{i2}^{\prime}=0.7\ \forall i\$ satisfies the definition of balanced data.

network reliability analyses

context.text: Each of the terms in \$B_{l}\$, and \$B_{u}\$, can be computed as presented in (1), and (2), or can be accurately approximated with the method presented in Ramirez-Marquez & Coit [27].

Finally, Sector 4 is approximated by [27], taking \$U\times G\$, and \$U\times Q\$ computations for the generated G capacitated minimal path vectors, and \$Q\$ capacitated minimal path vectors, respectively (i.e. \$O(UG)\$, and \$O(UQ)\$).

Finally, Step 4 utilizes the nominal component reliability along with both the CMCV, and CMPV to provide a bound for \${\rm C}2{\rm TR}_{d}\$. for this example, the simulation approach presented in Ramirez-Marquez & Coit [27] has been implemented to obtain both \$B_{l}\$, and \$B_{u}\$. for each of these bounds, the result yields 0.93614, and thus all the CMPV, and CMCV of the network have been obtained.

context.text: Finally, note that 1) the assumption that binary cut sets are known a-priori can be relaxed by applying a breath first search algorithm similar to [30], and 2) although the identification of all CMCV, and CMPV of a network is important to obtain exact reliability values, the results for these test cases show that in the absence of the complete set of such vectors the proposed method produces tight reliability bounds, even when link reliabilities are low.
